name: Civ Rev 2
enum3: III. Barter, Lease, and Contract for Piece of Work

children.name: Art. 1156
children.details: Obligation is the juridical necessity to give, to do or not to do. It is also defined as a juridical relation whereby a person (creditor) may demand from another (debtor) the observance of a determinate conduct, and in case of breach may obtain satisfaction from the assets of the latter.

children.name: Makati Stock Exchange v. Campos
children.details: A juridical relation whereby a person (creditor) may demand from another (debtor) the observance of a determinate conduct, and in case of breach may obtain satisfaction from the assets of the latter.

children.name: Essential Elements of Obligation
children.enum1: Juridical tie or vinculum juris
children.enum2: Object
children.enum3: Active subject
children.enum4: Passive subject

children.name: Sources of Obligations
children.enum1: Law
children.enum2: Contract
children.enum3: Quasi-contract
children.enum4: Delict
children.enum5: Quasi-delict

children.name: Ex Lege
children.details: Not presumed

children.name: Negotiorum gestio
children.details: Juridical relation that arises when a person voluntarily takes charge of the agency or management of another's abandoned or neglected business or property without the owner's authority

children.name: Effect of Death of the Accused
children.details: Obligation is the juridical necessity to give, to do or not to do. It is also defined as a juridical relation whereby a person (creditor) may demand from another (debtor) the observance of a determinate conduct, and in case of breach may obtain satisfaction from the assets of the latter.

children.name: Pure, Conditional, and Obligations with a Period
Principal Causes
children.enum1: a. Payment or performance
children.enum2: b. Loss of the Thing Due
children.enum3: c. Condonation or Remission of the Debt
children.enum4: d. Confusion or Merger of Rights
children.enum5: e. Compensation

children.name: Requisites
children.enum1: a. Complete and regular;
children.enum2: b. Tendered by the proper person;
children.enum3: c. Person making payment is capacitated;
children.enum4: d. Made to the proper person;
children.enum5: e. Person to whom payment is made must be capacitated;
children.enum6: f. Identity of the prestation must be preserved;
children.enum7: g. Tender made in the proper place

children.name: Loss of the Thing Due and Impossibility of Performance
Concept
children.details: It is understood that the thing is lost when:
children.enum1: a. The thing perishes;
children.enum2: b. Goes out of commerce;
children.enum3: c. Disappears in such a way that its existence is unknown or it cannot be recovered

children.name: Exceptions to Application
children.details: Generic Obligations - Genus of a thing can never perish. Genus nunquam perit.

children.name: Exception to the exception
children.details: Delimited Generic Obligations

children.name: Requisites for the Loss of Obligation
children.enum1: a. Obligation consists in the delivery of a determinate thing;
children.enum2: b. After the constitution of the obligation;
children.enum3: c. Debtor must not have any fault;
children.enum4: d. Loss occurs before delay;
children.enum5: e. Debtor must not have promised to deliver the thing to 2 or more persons who do not have the same interest

children.name: Condonation and Remission of Debt
children.details: Definition: It is an act of liberality renouncing the enforcement of an obligation without receiving the price or equivalent thereof

children.name: Requisites
children.enum1: a. Gratuitous;
children.enum2: b. Demandable;
children.enum3: c. Accepted by the obligor;
children.enum4: d. Must not be an inofficious donation;
children.enum5: e. If made expressly, must comply with the requisites for donation

children.name: Confusion and Merger of Rights
children.details: Definition: Meeting in one person of the qualities of debtor and creditor

children.name: Requisites of Confusion
children.enum1: a. Must take place in the person of the principal creditor and principal debtor;
children.enum2: b. Complete and definite

children.name: Compensation
children.details: Definition: Mode of extinguishing to the concurrent amounts the obligations of persons who are reciprocally debtors and creditors of each other

children.name: Requisites of Compensation
children.enum1: a. Parties must be principally debtors and creditors of each other;
children.enum2: b. Debt consists of a sum of money or of the same kind and quality, if consumable;
children.enum3: c. Both debts must be due;
children.enum4: d. Both debts must be liquidated and demandable;
children.enum5: e. No retention or controversy commenced by third persons over any of them

children.name: Novation
children.enum1: a. Changing its principal conditions;
children.enum2: b. Substitution of the debtor;
children.enum3: c. Subrogating a person in the rights of the creditor
children.details: Definition: Extinguishment of an obligation by:

children.name: Requisites of Novation
children.enum1: a. Previous valid obligation;
children.enum2: b. Agreement to the new contract;
children.enum3: c. Old contract must be extinguished;
children.enum4: d. Valid new contract

children.name: Other Causes (Expressly Mentioned)
children.enum1: 1) Annulment
children.enum2: 2) Rescission
children.enum3: 3) Fulfillment of Resolutory Condition
children.enum4: 4) Prescription

children.name: Other Causes (Not Expressly Mentioned)
children.enum1: 1) Death
children.enum2: 2) Arrival of Resolutory Period
children.enum3: 3) Mutual Consent
children.enum4: 4) Change of Civil Status, in some contracts
children.enum5: 5) Happening of Unforeseen Events

children.name: Art. 1305
children.details: A contract is a meeting of the minds between two persons whereby one binds himself, with respect to the other, to give something or to render some service.

children.name: Sanchez Roman in Jardine Davis v. CA
children.details: A juridical convention manifested in legal form, by virtue of which, one or more persons bind themselves in favor of another or others, or reciprocally, to the fulfillment of a prestation to give, to do, or not to do.

children.name: Characteristics of Contracts
children.enum1: a. Obligatory Force
children.enum2: b. Autonomy
children.enum3: c. Mutuality
children.enum4: d. Relativity

children.name: a. Obligatory Force
children.details: Obligations arising from contracts have the force of law between the contracting parties and should be complied with in good faith.

children.name: b. Autonomy
children.details: The   contracting   parties   may   establish   such stipulations, clauses, terms and conditions as they may deem convenient, provided they are not contrary to law, morals, good customs, public order, or public policy.

children.name: c. Mutuality
children.details: The contract must bind both contracting parties. Its validity or compliance cannot be left to the will of one of them.

children.name: Relativity
children.details: GR: Contracts take effect only between the parties, their assigns and heirs

children.name: Exception to Relativity
children.details: When the rights and obligations are not transmissible a. By nature; b. Stipulation; c. Law
children.enum1: a. Stipulation pour autrui;
children.enum2: b. Provisions of mortgage laws and land registration laws;
children.enum3: c. Contracts intended to defraud creditors;
children.enum4: d. Accion directa (in contracts for a piece of work);
children.enum5: e. Tortious interference

children.name: Contract of Adhesion
children.details: One  in  which  one  of the  parties  imposes  a ready-made  form  of contract, which the other party may accept or reject, but which the latter cannot modify.

children.name: Rules on Contracts of Adhesion
children.enum1: GR: Contracts of adhesion are valid.
children.enum2: Except: When the weaker party is imposed upon in dealing with the dominant bargaining party and is reduced to the alternative of taking it or leaving it, completely deprived of the opportunity to bargain on equal footing.

children.name: Requisites for Stipulation Pour Autri
children.enum1: a. Stipulation in favor of a third person;
children.enum2: b. Must be a part, not the whole of the contract;
children.enum3: c. Deliberate conferment and not a mere incidental benefit;
children.enum4: d. Communication of acceptance before revocation;
children.enum5: e. Neither of the contracting parties bears the legal representation or authorization of the third party

children.name: Tortious interference
children.details: Any third person who induces another to violate his contract shall be liable for damages to the other contracting party. Requisites are:
children.enum1: a. Valid contract;
children.enum2: b. Third party’s knowledge of the contract;
children.enum3: c. Interference without legal justification or excuse

children.name: Essential Requisites of Contracts
children.enum1: 1) Consent
children.enum2: 2) Object
children.enum3: 3) Cause

children.name: Requisites of Consent
children.enum1: a. Plurality of subjects
children.enum2: b. Capacity
children.enum3: c. Intelligence
children.enum4: d. Express or tacit manifestation of will
children.enum5: e. Conformity of the internal will and its manifestation

children.name: Persons Incapable of Giving Consent
children.enum1: a. Minors;
children.enum2: b. Insane or demented persons;
children.enum3: c. Deaf-mutes who do not know how to write;
children.enum4: d. Suffering from civil interdiction;
children.enum5: e. Incompetents under guardianship

children.name: Minors
children.enum1: GR: Contracts entered into by minors are voidable
children.enum2: Exception: Active Misrepresentation. Where the minors who entered into the contract have already passed the age of puberty and adolescence in such a way that they could misrepresent and actually did misrepresent themselves as having reached the age of majority, they cannot, upon reaching the age of majority, annul the contract on the ground of minority inasmuch as they are already in estoppel.

children.name: Requisites of Objects of Contracts
children.enum1: a. Within the commerce of men
children.enum2: b. Real or possible, either physically or legally
children.enum3: c. Not contrary to law, morals, good customs, public order, or public policy.
children.enum4: d. Determinate or determinable as to its kind

children.name: Contract upon Future Inheritance
children.enum1: GR: Contracts upon a future inheritance are prohibited
children.enum2: Exception: Partition of estate inter vivos, provided that the legitime of compulsory heirs is not prejudiced

children.name: Elements of a Contract upon Future Inheritance
children.enum1: a. Succession has not yet been opened;
children.enum2: b. Object of the contract forms part of the inheritance;
children.enum3: c. The promisor has, with respect to the object, an expectancy of a right which is purely hereditary in nature

children.name: Cause
children.details: Cause is the essential reason which moves the contracting parties to enter to it – it is the immediate, direct and proximate reason which justifies the creation of an obligation through the will of the contracting parties.

children.name: Requisites for Cause and Consideration
children.enum1: Must exist
children.enum2: True
children.enum3: Licit

children.name: Motive
children.enum1: GR: The parties’ motives for entering a contract do not affect the contract.
children.enum2: Exception: The motive may  be regarded  as  the causa  when  the realization of such motive or particular purpose has been made a condition upon which the contract is made to depend.

children.name: Forms of Contracts
children.enum1: a. Validity;
children.enum2: b. Enforceability;
children.enum3: c. Proving them in a certain way
children.details: GR: Contracts shall be obligatory, in whatever form they may have been entered into, provided all the essential requisites for their validity are present. Exceptions: Those required to be in some form for:

children.name: Contracts which Require Form for Validity
children.enum1: Donation of personal property where the value exceeds P5k
children.enum2: Donation of real property
children.enum3: Donation propter nuptias
children.enum4: Contract of partnership when real property is contributed as capital
children.enum5: Sale of land by an agent
children.enum8: Sale or Transfer of Large Cattle, and Chattel mortgage

children.name: Contracts which Require Form for Enforceability
children.enum1: a. Those that fall under the Statute of Frauds;
children.enum2: b. Express trust over an immovable;
children.enum3: c. Agreement on payment of interest

children.name: Contracts which Require Form for Convenience
children.enum1: a.  Creation,  transmission,  modification  or  extinguishment  of  real rights over immovable property;
children.enum2: b. Cession, repudiation or renunciation of hereditary rights or of those of the conjugal partnership of gains;
children.enum3: c. The power to administer property, or any other power which has for its object an act appearing or which should appear in a public document, or should prejudice a third person;
children.enum4: d. Cession of actions or rights proceeding from an act appearing in a public document.

children.name: Requisites for Exercise of Right to Compel Observation of the Required Form
children.enum1: a. Contract must have already been perfected;
children.enum2: b. Must have been valid as to its form;
children.enum3: c. Must have been enforceable under the Statute of Frauds

children.name: Reformation and Contract Interpretation
children.details: Remedy in equity by means of which a written instrument is made or construed so as to express or conform to the real intention of the parties.

children.name: Requisites of Reformation
children.enum1: a. Meeting of minds between the parties;
children.enum2: b. The instrument does not express the true intention of the parties;
children.enum3: c. The failure to express the true intention of the parties is due to:
children.enum4: i. Mistake;
children.enum5: ii. Fraud;

children.name: Requisites for Reformation due to Mutual Mistake
children.enum1: a. Mistake of fact;
children.enum2: b. Proved by clear and convincing evidence;
children.enum3: c. Common to both parties

children.name: Requisites of Simulation of Contracts
children.enum1: a. Outward declaration of will different from the will of the parties;
children.enum2: b. False appearance must have been intended by mutual agreement;
children.enum3: c. Purpose is to deceive third persons

children.name: Absolute vs. Relative Simulation
children.enum1: Absolute - The  parties  do  not  have  any intention to be bound at all; Remedy: To declare the contract void
children.enum2: Relative - The parties simply conceal their true agreement; Remedy: Reformation

children.name: Rescission
children.details: A remedy granted by law to the contracting parties and even to third persons, to secure the reparation of damages caused to them by a contract, even if this should be valid, by restoration of things to their condition at the moment prior to the celebration of the contract.

children.name: Characteristics of Rescissible Contracts
children.enum1: a. Valid and enforceable until they are rescinded by a competent court;
children.enum2: b. Cause pecuniary lesion or prejudice;
children.enum3: c. Defect may not be cured by ratification;
children.enum4: d. Cannot be attacked collaterally

children.name: Requisites for Rescission to Prosper
children.enum1: a. The ground must be any of those specified in Art. 1381 and 1382;
children.enum2: b. No other legal means to obtain reparation for the damage;
children.enum3: c. Person demanding must be able to return what he may be obliged to restore;
children.enum4: d. The things which are the object of the contract must not be in the possession of third persons who did not act in bad faith;
children.enum5: e. Must be filed within 4 years from accrual of action

children.name: Rescissible Contracts
children.enum1: a. Entered into by guardians of wards when the latter suffer lesion by more than ¼ of the value of the object of the contract;
children.enum2: b. Entered into by representatives of absentees when the latter suffer the same lesion;
children.enum3: c. Undertaken in fraud of creditors;
children.enum4: d. Refers to things under litigation, without knowledge and approval;
children.enum5: e. Declared by law

children.name: Badges of Fraud
children.enum1: a. Consideration is fictitious or inadequate;
children.enum2: b. Transfer made by a debtor after suit has begun and while pending;
children.enum3: c. Sale upon credit by an insolvent debtor;
children.enum4: d. Evidence of large indebtedness or insolvency;
children.enum5: e. Transfer of all or nearly all property by a debtor, especially when he is insolvent or greatly embarrassed financially;
children.enum6: f. Transfer made between father and son, with any of (a) to (e);
children.enum7: g. Vendee’s failure to take exclusive possession of all the property

children.name: Contracts Declared by Law to be Rescissible
children.enum1: a. When there is lesion in a partition;
children.enum2: b. Breach of one party in reciprocal obligations;
children.enum3: c. When the debtor is deprived of the right of choice in alternative obligations;
children.enum4: d. Unpaid seller;
children.enum5: e. Inferior value or lack in area of real estate exceeding 1/10 of the price agreed upon;
children.enum6: f. Failure to deliver an immovable;
children.enum7: g. Eviction of a substantial portion of property sold;

children.name: Contracts Declared by Law to be Rescissible (cont)
children.enum1: h. Loss of one of the things sold jointly for a lump sum;
children.enum2: i. Sale of an immovable encumbered with a non-apparent burden;
children.enum3: j. Failure of either party to comply with obligations under a contract of lease;
children.enum4: k. Adoption;
children.enum5: l.  Deterioration  of the object  through  the debtor’s  fault,  pending fulfillment of a suspensive condition

children.name: Characteristics of a Voidable Contract
children.enum1: a. Valid and binding until annulled;
children.enum2: b. Suffers a defect in the form of vitiation of consent;
children.enum3: c. May become valid through ratification;
children.enum4: d. May be convalidated through prescription;
children.enum5: e. Cannot be collaterally attacked

children.name: Annulment
children.details: A contract that is annulled presupposes that it subsists but later ceases to have legal effect when it is terminated through court action.
children.enum1: Who Can Invoke: GR - The incapacitated contracting parties only
children.enum2: Except: A non-party who:
children.enum3: a. Is prejudiced; AND
children.enum4: b.  Can  show  detriment which  would  positively result to him
children.enum5: Defect: Intrinsic (Consent)

children.name: Rescission
children.enum1: Who Can Invoke: Contracting  parties and third persons who have been prejudiced
children.enum2: Defect: Extrinsic (Damage)
children.enum3: Basis: Equity
children.enum4: Ratification: Impossible

children.name: Grounds for Annulment
children.enum1: a. One of the parties is incapable of giving consent to a contract;
children.enum2: b.  Consent  is  vitiated  by  mistake,  violence,  intimidation,  undue influence or fraud

children.name: Vitiation of Consent
children.enum1: a. Mistake
children.enum2: b. Fraud
children.enum3: c. Violence
children.enum4: d. Intimidation
children.enum5: e. Undue Influence

children.name: Mistake
children.details: In order that a mistake may invalidate consent, it should either refer to:
children.enum1: a. Substance of the thing which is the object of the contract;
children.enum2: b. Conditions which have principally moved one or  both parties to contract;
children.enum3: c. Identity or qualifications of a party when it is the principal cause

children.name: Fraud
children.details: Insidious  words  or  machinations resorted to by one of the parties to induce the other to enter into a contract which without them he would not have agreed to

children.name: Requisites of Annulment Based on Fraud
children.enum1: a. Employed by one party  upon the other;
children.enum2: b. Induced the other party to enter into the contract;
children.enum3: c. Serious;
children.enum4: d. Damage and injury to the party seeking annulment;

children.name: Violence
children.details: In order to wrest consent, serious or irresistible force is employed

children.name: Intimidation
children.details: One of the parties is compelled by a reasonable and well-grounded fear of an imminent and grave peril upon his person or property, or that of his spouse, descendants or ascendants to give his consent

children.name: Requisites of Annulment based on Intimidation
children.enum1: a. Determining cause of the contract;
children.enum2: b. Threatened act is unjust or unlawful
children.enum3: c. Real and serious;
children.enum4: d. Produces  a  reasonable  and well-grounded fear from  the fact  that  the person  from  whom it comes has the necessary means or ability to inflict the threatened injury

children.name: Undue Influence
children.details: A person takes improper advantage of his power over the will of another, depriving the latter of a reasonable freedom of choice

children.name: Requisites of Annulment Based on Undue Influence
children.enum1: a. A  person  who  can  be  influenced;
children.enum2: b. Improper influence was exerted;
children.enum3: c. Submission to the overwhelming effect of such unlawful conduct

children.name: Characteristics
children.enum1: a. Valid contracts but cannot be enforced by a proper action in court;
children.enum2: b. Susceptible of ratification;
children.enum3: c. The defect is of a permanent nature and will exist as long as the contract is not duly ratified;
children.enum4: d. Cannot be assailed by third persons

children.name: Kinds of Unenforceable Contracts
children.enum1: a. Entered into in the name of another person by one who has been given no authority or representation, or who has acted beyond his powers;
children.enum2: b. Do not comply with the Statute of Frauds;
children.enum3: c. Both parties are incapable of giving consent

children.name: NOTE
children.details: A sale of realty of the ward or the absentee by the guardian or legal representative without authority from the court is void, not merely unenforceable.

children.name: Statute of Frauds
children.details: Statutes which require certain classes of contracts to be in writing to be enforceable. It provides the method by which the contracts enumerated therein may be proved but does not declare them invalid because they are not reduced to writing.

children.name: Characteristics of Void and Inexistent Contracts
children.enum1: a. Not susceptible of ratification;
children.enum2: b. Right to set up the defense of inexistence or illegality cannot be waived or renounced;
children.enum3: c. Action or defense for declaration of nullity does not prescribe;
children.enum4: d. Nullity cannot be invoked by a person whose interests are not directly affected;
children.enum5: e. Generally produce no effect whatsoever

children.name: Void
children.details: All the essential elements are present but the contract is invalid from its inception. Principle of pari delicto is applicable so it can produce legal effects. Kinds:
children.enum1: a. Cause, object or purpose is contrary to LMGPP;
children.enum2: b. Object it outside the commerce of man;
children.enum3: c. Contemplate an impossible service;
children.enum4: d. Expressly prohibited or declared void by law

children.name: Inexistent
children.details: Any of the essential requisites for the existence of a contract is totally wanting. Kinds:
children.enum1: a. Absolutely simulated or fictitious;
children.enum2: b. Cause or object did not exist at the time of the transaction;
children.enum3: c. Intention of the parties relative to the principal object of the contract cannot be ascertained
